prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This setup obtains the dense gas tracers HCN and HCO+ and their optically thin isotopologues H13CN and H13CO+, all in the J=1-0 transition. The setup also provides for one continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 pc2 region extending along a dense filament that is furthermore mostly dark at mid-infrared wavelengths, southeast of the HII region G353.1+0.6. It includes seven massive clumps.
Sensitivity: line emission
The peak HCN flux in the region is likely to come from the brightest clump, #132. We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Clump 109 has T_MB=5.7 K (125 Jy) with MOPRA (resolution 36” = 0.33 pc). Emission is likely localized to regions on the order of 0.1 pc in size (e.g. Brogan et al. 2009 study of clump NGC 6334 I(N)), implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). Thus we expect a peak flux of about 5.0 Jy in this region. However, line emission is likely orders of magnitude lower between cores. We thus estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have T_MB = 0.6 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 528 mJy using the above assumptions. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (> 10 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic. The optically thin isotopologues are significantly weaker (as low as 176 mJy predicted peak flux with our setup), but our sensitivity should still provide > 3 sigma detections of at least the clump regions.
Sensitivity: continuum
Beuther et al. (2010) derived peak intensities of 13-55 mJy/beam at 3.4 mm with ATCA in the cores associated with the source NGC 6334 I(N). Since our synthesized beam is of comparable size, we take the average (34 mJy) as our expected peak continuum flux. With the above line sensitivity, we achieve a sensitivity of 0.21 mJy (1 sigma) and a signal-to-noise > 150. This should be more than sufficient to trace the extended dust structure within this region. Continuum data can be combined with the continuum observations taken in the N2H+/HNC spectral setup for increased sensitivity, if needed.
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, distinguishing between star formation modes and understanding the scales on which each operates necessitates high fidelity at all spatial scales. Our resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc) allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in many cases (Russeil et al. 2010). Furthermore, these lines are excellent tracers of infall motions, but high resolution is needed to separate blue- and red-shifted components to detect infall and measure its velocity. A resolution of 0.12 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for HCN and HCO+ is needed to separate velocity and spatially separated components, distinguish hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. A slightly coarser resolution of 0.24 km/s for the optically thin isotopologues should be sufficient to still resolve them, and the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. These lines are important in deriving systemic velocities for cores and validating the kinematic signatures of the optically thick lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

This setup obtains the dense gas tracers HCN and HCO+ and their optically thin isotopologues H13CN and H13CO+, all in the J=1-0 transition. The setup also provides for one continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 square pc region along an infrared-bright filament between optically bright regions G353.1+0.6 and G353.24+0.64 and the large shell in NGC 6357. It includes five massive clumps, including three with masses > 200 Msun.
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Emission is likely localized to regions on the order of 0.1 pc in size (e.g. Brogan et al. 2009 study of clump NGC 6334 I(N)), implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). We estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have T_MB = 0.6 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 528 mJy using the above assumptions, which is the number we select for peak flux in the region. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (> 10 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic. The optically thin isotopologues are significantly weaker (as low as 176 mJy predicted peak flux with our setup), but our sensitivity should still provide > 3 sigma detections of at least the clump regions.
Sensitivity: continuum
Same as 1st science goal
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, obtaining reliable maps of the 10 square pc mosaic region, distinguishing between star formation modes, understanding the scales on which each operates, and making accurate predictions relevant to extragalactic all necessitate having high fidelity at all spatial scales. Our resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc) allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357, achieving a spatial dynamic range of ~500. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores, so we stress the importance of including these short-spacing and total power observations.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in some cases (Russeil et al. 2010). Furthermore, HCN and HCO+ are excellent tracers of infall motions, but high resolution is needed to separate blue- and red-shifted components to detect infall and measure its velocity. A resolution of 0.12 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for HCN and HCO+ is needed to separate velocity and spatially separated components, accurately model hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. A slightly coarser resolution of 0.24 km/s for the optically thin isotopologues should be sufficient to still detect them, and the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. These lines are important in deriving systemic velocities for cores and validating the kinematic signatures of the optically thick lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

This setup obtains the dense gas tracers HCN and HCO+ and their optically thin isotopologues H13CN and H13CO+, all in the J=1-0 transition. The setup also provides for one continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 square pc region spanning the HII regions G353.2+0.9 and G353.19+0.84, one portion of the large shell, the molecular-ionized gas interface, and associated photon-dominated regions. It includes five massive clumps, including two with masses > 200 Msun that are thought to be compact HII regions.
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Emission is likely localized to regions on the order of 0.1 pc in size (e.g. Brogan et al. 2009 study of clump NGC 6334 I(N)), implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). We estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have T_MB = 0.6 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 528 mJy using the above assumptions, which is the number we select for peak flux in the region. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (> 10 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic. The optically thin isotopologues are significantly weaker (as low as 176 mJy predicted peak flux with our setup), but our sensitivity should still provide > 3 sigma detections of at least the clump regions.
Sensitivity: continuum
same as 1st science goal
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, obtaining reliable maps of the 10 square pc mosaic region, distinguishing between star formation modes, understanding the scales on which each operates, and making accurate predictions relevant to extragalactic all necessitate having high fidelity at all spatial scales. Our resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc) allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357, achieving a spatial dynamic range of ~500. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores, so we stress the importance of including these short-spacing and total power observations.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in some cases (Russeil et al. 2010). Furthermore, HCN and HCO+ are excellent tracers of infall motions, but high resolution is needed to separate blue- and red-shifted components to detect infall and measure its velocity. A resolution of 0.12 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for HCN and HCO+ is needed to separate velocity and spatially separated components, accurately model hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. A slightly coarser resolution of 0.24 km/s for the optically thin isotopologues should be sufficient to still detect them, and the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. These lines are important in deriving systemic velocities for cores and validating the kinematic signatures of the optically thick lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

This setup focuses on the quiescent gas tracer N2H+(1-0) and HCN’s isomer HNC(1-0). It also obtains the N2H+ isotopologue N15N2H+(1-0) and 13CS(2-1) in the third baseband, and a continuum band. The mosaic is identical to that of the NW HCN/HCO+ mosaic. To restate, the mosaic covers a ~10 square pc region spanning the HII regions G353.2+0.9 and G353.19+0.84, one portion of the large shell, the molecular-ionized gas interface, and associated photon-dominated regions. It includes four massive clumps, including two with masses > 200 Msun that are thought to be compact HII regions.
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Emission from N2H+ is likely localized within star-forming cores of sizes ~0.1 pc, implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). Thus we expect a peak flux of about 1.4 Jy in this region. We estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have N2H+(1-0) T_MB = 0.2 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 176 mJy using the above assumptions, which is the number we select for peak flux in the region. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (3 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic in which all clumps should be detected. HNC emission is on average only slightly weaker than that of HCN, and so this sensitivity (which is equivalent to that reached in our HCN setup) should handily detect it.
Sensitivity: continuum
Beuther et al. (2010) derived peak intensities of 13-55 mJy/beam at 3.4 mm with ATCA in the cores associated with the source NGC 6334 I(N). Since our synthesized beam is of comparable size, we take the average (34 mJy) as our expected peak continuum flux. With the above line sensitivity, we achieve a sensitivity of 0.21 mJy (1 sigma) and a signal-to-noise > 150. This should be more than sufficient to trace the extended dust structure within this region. Continuum data can be combined with the continuum observations taken in the HCN/HCO+ spectral setup for increased sensitivity, if needed.
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, distinguishing between star formation modes and understanding the scales on which each operates necessitates high fidelity at all spatial scales. Our resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc) allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in many cases (Russeil et al. 2010). N2H+ consists of seven hyperfine components spaced as closely as a few tenths of a km/s apart. A resolution of 0.11 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for N2H+ is needed to separate velocity components, distinguish hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. We use this same resolution for HNC to match the resolution of HCN in the other spectral setup. We use a coarser resolution of 0.9 km/s for 13CS(2-1) and N15NH+, as the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

This setup focuses on the quiescent gas tracer N2H+(1-0) and HCN’s isomer HNC(1-0). It also obtains the N2H+ isotopologue N15N2H+(1-0) and 13CS(2-1) in the third baseband, and a continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 pc2 region extending along a dense filament that is furthermore mostly dark at mid-infrared wavelengths, southeast of the HII region G353.1+0.6. It includes seven massive clumps.
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Emission from N2H+ is likely localized within star-forming cores of sizes ~0.1 pc, implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). We estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have N2H+(1-0) T_MB = 0.2 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 176 mJy using the above assumptions. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (>3 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic in which all clumps should be detected. HNC emission is on average only slightly weaker than that of HCN, and so this sensitivity (which is equivalent to that reached in our HCN setup) should handily detect it. 13CS(2-1) and N15NH+ are likely significantly weaker, but coarsening the spectral resolution should allow for significant detections in at least the strongest sources. These lines are not a main goal of the proposal, so we do not count on their detection.
Sensitivity: continuum
Beuther et al. (2010) derived peak intensities of 13-55 mJy/beam at 3.4 mm with ATCA in the cores associated with the source NGC 6334 I(N). Since our synthesized beam is of comparable size, we take the average (34 mJy) as our expected peak continuum flux. With the above line sensitivity, we achieve a sensitivity of 0.21 mJy (1 sigma) and a signal-to-noise > 150. This should be more than sufficient to trace the extended dust structure within this region. Continuum data can be combined with the continuum observations taken in the HCN/HCO+ spectral setup for increased sensitivity, if needed.
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, distinguishing between star formation modes and understanding the scales on which each operates necessitates high fidelity at all spatial scales. We propose to use the C34-2 configuration, which provides a resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). This allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores. Despite short integrations per pointing, simulations have shown that the UV coverage is sufficient.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in many cases (Russeil et al. 2010). N2H+ consists of seven hyperfine components spaced as closely as a few tenths of a km/s apart. A resolution of 0.11 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for N2H+ is needed to separate velocity components, distinguish hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. We use this same resolution for HNC to match the resolution of HCN in the other spectral setup. We use a coarser resolution of 0.9 km/s for 13CS(2-1) and N15NH+, as the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

This setup focuses on the quiescent gas tracer N2H+(1-0) and HCN’s isomer HNC(1-0). It also obtains the N2H+ isotopologue N15N2H+(1-0) and 13CS(2-1) in the third baseband, and a continuum band. The mosaic covers a ~10 square pc region along an infrared-bright filament between optically bright regions G353.1+0.6 and G353.24+0.64 and the large shell in NGC 6357. It includes five massive clumps, including three with masses > 200 Msun.
Sensitivity: line emission
We have downloaded the publicly available MOPRA spectra of Russeil et al. (2010), and used their peak fluxes as predictions for the sensitivity calculations. Emission from N2H+ is likely localized within star-forming cores of sizes ~0.1 pc, implying a reduction of flux by a factor of at most 25 at the ALMA synthesized beam resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). We estimate the needed sensitivity to detect extended structure in the mosaic from the faintest clumps in the Russeil sample, which have N2H+(1-0) T_MB = 0.2 K with MOPRA. This translates into an expected ALMA flux of 176 mJy using the above assumptions. We select a sensitivity of 50 mJy to best balance needed sensitivity (>3 sigma detections for all clump-like structures) with observing time (18 s per pointing for this sensitivity) to allow for a large mosaic in which all clumps should be detected. HNC emission is on average only slightly weaker than that of HCN, and so this sensitivity (which is equivalent to that reached in our HCN setup) should handily detect it. 13CS(2-1) and N15NH+ are likely significantly weaker, but coarsening the spectral resolution should allow for significant detections in at least the strongest sources. These lines are not a main goal of the proposal, so we do not count on their detection.
Sensitivity: continuum
Beuther et al. (2010) derived peak intensities of 13-55 mJy/beam at 3.4 mm with ATCA in the cores associated with the source NGC 6334 I(N). Since our synthesized beam is of comparable size, we take the average (34 mJy) as our expected peak continuum flux. With the above line sensitivity, we achieve a sensitivity of 0.21 mJy (1 sigma) and a signal-to-noise > 150. This should be more than sufficient to trace the extended dust structure within this region. Continuum data can be combined with the continuum observations taken in the HCN/HCO+ spectral setup for increased sensitivity, if needed.
Imaging
Our science goals require extremely high spatial dynamic range. In particular, distinguishing between star formation modes and understanding the scales on which each operates necessitates high fidelity at all spatial scales. We propose to use the C34-2 configuration, which provides a resolution of 2.2” (0.02 pc). This allows us to probe the thousand-AU scales of individual cores, while the use of the ACA recovers the extended structure clearly seen in previous studies of NGC 6357. As measured through simulations by Offner et al. (2011), the lack of ACA coverage can lead to misleading results regarding the substructure of star-forming cores. Despite short integrations per pointing, simulations have shown that the UV coverage is sufficient.
Correlator setup
Linewidths of clumps in this region are measured to be 1-2 km/s, but there are likely multiple components along the line of sight in many cases (Russeil et al. 2010). N2H+ consists of seven hyperfine components spaced as closely as a few tenths of a km/s apart. A resolution of 0.11 km/s (after Hanning smoothing) for N2H+ is needed to separate velocity components, distinguish hyperfine structure, and trace velocity dispersion down to near thermal values. We use this same resolution for HNC to match the resolution of HCN in the other spectral setup. We use a coarser resolution of 0.9 km/s for 13CS(2-1) and N15NH+, as the higher sensitivity will aid in detecting these weaker lines. We bin spectra by 2 channels to reduce the data rate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The majority of our observational knowledge of the star formation process is derived from studies of nearby low-mass regions, yet the majority of the energy and momentum involved in star formation is connected to massive stars. This imbalance in our understanding is a result of the relative inaccessibility of massive star-forming regions to high-spatial resolution observations. Further progress in this area requires investigation into both the substructure of star-forming clouds (at the scales of prestellar cores) and the environmental medium in which these cores form and evolve. We propose to undertake a comprehensive investigation of the dense molecular ISM in the massive star-forming region NGC 6357 with ALMA. We will map three regions in varying environmental conditions in 3.3 mm continuum and the dense gas tracers HCN, HCO+, N2H+, and several of their isotopologues at 0.1 km/s resolution. We will investigate the interconnected structure of the ISM from ~5000 AU scales up to our mosaic size of ~5 pc, model our results to attempt to discriminate between various modes of star formation, and extrapolate to other galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
